headline.main: True Secret Of Fad Diets: It's Calories

docs.abstract: Gina Kolata column debunks weight-loss claims made for high-protein, low-carb diets; says that there are no magical food to make you gain or lose weight and that all that mattters is calories, now matter what foods they come from (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: One of my most vivid childhood memories is a diet -- not for me but for my father. Year after year he would take it up, poring over a few sheets of typed instructions given to him by a family doctor, the ancient and rail thin Dr. M. D. Levin of Baltimore. Dr. Levin's diet was supposed to cure ulcers and prevent migraines, to give you energy and robust health. But, most important, to make you lose weight. It was a high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet, not so different from the diets sweeping the country today. You load up on meats and cut all the good stuff, like pasta and bread and dessert.
